description: Rike Park is a modern urban park opened in 2010 on the left bank of the Kura River in the heart of Old Tbilisi. Designed by Italian architect Michele De Lucchi, it transformed a former asphalt field used for driving lessons into a vibrant public space that has become one of Tbilisi's most famous attractions. The park features futuristic architecture, interactive installations, and serves as the gateway to Narikala Fortress via cable car.
highlights: Bridge of Peace - stunning pedestrian bridge with wave-like structure illuminated by thousands of LED lights at night
Aerial cable car connecting to Narikala Fortress - 5-7 minute ride with breathtaking city views
Large open-air amphitheater hosting concerts, performances, and cultural events year-round
Two tubular metallic structures by Massimiliano and Doriana Fuksas - future Music Theater and Exhibition Hall
Panoramic views of the Kura River, Old Tbilisi, and surrounding mountains
Park layout forms a large-scale map of Georgia when viewed from above, with pathways depicting regions
Interactive features: giant white piano, life-size chessboard, artificial climbing wall, and maze for children
Musical fountain with evening light shows during warmer seasons
Modern art sculptures and installations throughout the park
Beautifully manicured gardens and walking paths
tips: Cable car requires Metromoney Card (2 GEL refundable deposit) - no cash accepted, ride costs 2.5 GEL
Cable car operates 12 PM to 8:30 PM typically, but hours vary seasonally
Visit just before sunset for magical lighting and twinkling city lights after dark
Consider descending from Narikala via mountain trails instead of cable car for scenic adventure
Dress warmly even in summer - it's very windy on the mountain
Cannot ride cable car with food in hands (put in backpack) or open metal cans
Wait times minimal except during peak seasons, weekends, and holidays
Narikala Fortress closed for renovations until late 2025, but viewpoints and Mother of Georgia statue accessible
Best visited in evening for light shows and illuminated Bridge of Peace
Free entry to the park, perfect for families with children
Great spot for photography, especially at night
Cable car cabins hold up to 8 passengers
vibe: Modern, vibrant, and family-friendly with a futuristic aesthetic that contrasts beautifully with Old Tbilisi. The park buzzes with energy from locals and tourists enjoying interactive installations, cultural events, and stunning river views. Evening transforms the space into a magical wonderland with illuminated architecture and fountain shows.
expectations: A sleek modern park with cutting-edge architecture
Quick cable car ride to fortress viewpoint
Standard public park with benches and green spaces
reality: An award-winning urban design masterpiece that merged historical space with modern innovation
A living cultural hub hosting major festivals like Tbilisoba and International Theatre Festival
An interactive playground with giant pianos, chess boards, and art installations beloved by locals
A vital community space equally popular with Tbilisi residents as with tourists
unique_facts: The entire park layout forms a map of Georgia when viewed from above, with meandering pathways depicting the country's various regions
Before 2010, this area was just a huge asphalt field where people practiced driving
Designed by renowned Italian architect Michele De Lucchi and won several prestigious awards for innovative design
The metallic tubular concert hall and exhibition center structures were designed by Italian architects Massimiliano and Doriana Fuksas
Hosts Tbilisoba Festival every October, celebrating Tbilisi's diversity, culture, and history with culinary exhibitions and agricultural fairs
The Bridge of Peace connecting the park features a skeleton made of steel covered with glass roof, creating spectacular LED light displays
In 2019, hosted the Tbilisi International Festival of Theatre
The cable car was one of the first modern aerial tramways installed in Tbilisi's historic center
Part of major 2010 urban revitalization project transforming industrial areas into vibrant public spaces
The park's design intentionally creates a dialogue between Tbilisi's ancient past and modern future
surprises: The park doubles as a giant geographic map - you can literally walk across Georgia's regions
What was once a driving practice lot is now an internationally acclaimed urban design showcase
The giant interactive piano and chessboard aren't just decorations - locals actively use them
Evening musical fountain shows rival any European capital's water displays
The cable car requires a metro card system, not simple tickets - plan accordingly
Mountain winds are significantly stronger than expected, even on warm days
The park feels equally authentic to locals as tourists - not a manufactured attraction
Those futuristic metal tubes are still unfinished concert halls years after opening
Descending from Narikala on foot reveals hidden trails more beautiful than the cable car ride up
The park transforms completely at night - it's essentially two different experiences
